docs.lead_paragraph: There are tens of millions of people without insurance, often for extended periods, and there is good evidence that lack of insurance is harmful to their health.

docs.lead_paragraph: Any death watch for a health care overhaul may be premature. But with the White House on the defensive, and polls showing public support on the wane, advance obituaries are starting to be written. If the effort fails, here may be some of the commonly cited causes:
docs.abstract: Obama administration is on defensive in debate over health care overhaul; some people are already speculating on factors that might cause its failure, including absence of former Sen Tom Daschle from process, fixation on avoiding mistakes of Clintons, pent-up anger on right and lack of specific bill; Pres Obama appears unlikely to give up on bill (M)
docs.snippet: Any death watch for a health care overhaul may be premature. But with the White House on the defensive, and polls showing public support on the wane, advance obituaries are starting to be written.     If the effort fails, here may be some of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The first rule of retail marketing? Know your customers. Which is why it was surprising that the chief executive of Whole Foods Market, John P. Mackey, recently took a very public stand against government involvement in health care -- a view that might seem antithetical to those of the company's more stereotypical buyers of edamame and organic figs.
docs.abstract: Whole Foods chief executive John P Mackey's Wall Street Journal Op-Ed article opposing health care overhaul has led to calls for boycotts of Whole Foods stores by customers who feel deceived; notes that company has spent considerable effort responding to customers' complaints even though protest has had no discernible impact on sales; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama sought to dispel what he called ''willful misrepresentations and outright distortions'' in the health care debate, saying in an address broadcast on Saturday that illegal immigrants would not receive health insurance. ''That idea has never even been on the table,'' Mr. Obama said in his weekly radio and Internet address.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama attempts to address misinformation about health care overhaul in his regular weekly address, particularly charges that illegal immigrants would be covered and that reform will bring about government takeover of health care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama seems to be starting his own version of Discovery Channel's MythBusters. For the second consecutive week Mr. Obama used his weekly address to dispel what he called the "outrageous myths" circulating about his health care proposal.
docs.abstract: President Obama, in his radio address, tries to refute criticisms of his health care proposals.
docs.snippet: President Obama, in his radio address, tries to refute criticisms of his health care proposals.
